question_sentence: The world’s busiest airport for international travel saw 29 million visitors last year. Where is it located?
It was announced this week that which popular daytime television show was ending in June?
The Beijing Olympics came to a close this week. The U.S. finished with the fifth most medals at the Games with how many?
Chess prodigy Rameshbabu Praggnanandhaa became the youngest person to beat the world's No. 1 player Magnus Carlsen. How old is he?
The Oscars announced they would present eight awards off-air during next month’s telecast. Which of these is one of those awards?
After burning for a week, a fire on a cargo ship in the middle of the ocean has finally gone out. What was it hauling?
Family Dollar closed 404 stores in 6 states and announced a recall affecting thousands of items. What was the reason?
choices: Rodent infestation at a distribution facility

question_sentence: A 19-year-old had both legs and all of his fingers amputated after eating leftovers from a restaurant. What were the leftovers?
Singer Jane 'Nightbirde' Marczewski died Saturday at age 31 after battling cancer for four years. On which TV show was she a contestant?
A Tennessee woman was swindled out of $390,000 in a cryptocurrency scam by a man she met where?
Who was Defence Secretary Ben Wallace addressing when he accused Vladimir Putin of having gone ‘full tonto’ following his decision to launch a full-scale invasion of Ukraine?
evidence: Wallace was filmed making the comments as he spoke to serving military personnel at the Horse Guards building in Westminster

question_sentence: Why was German tennis player Alexander Zverev kicked out of the Mexican Open?
choices: Kicking a tennis ball into the crowd
Attacking the umpire's chair with his racket
evidence: The world No. 3 ranked player was fined $40,000 dollars, forfeited more than $30,000 in prize money and lost all of his rankings points from the tournament

question_sentence: Boris Johnson became the first sitting prime minister to be questioned under police caution, but how was he quizzed about his role in the Downing Street lockdown gatherings?
evidence: The Metropolitan Police sent questionnaires to almost 90 people thought to have attended Downing Street parties. The prime minister is understood to have already returned the police questionnaire after first taking legal advice

question_sentence: Nasa has announced plans to officially decommission the International Space Station (ISS) in 2031, but how long has it been in operation so far?
evidence: Originally commissioned for a 15-year lifespan, the ISS has been in operation for 21 years. Nasa has given the go-ahead for one more decade, doubling its total planned time in orbit

question_sentence: US freedom of speech charities have warned of an ‘unprecedented’ rise in calls for books to be banned or censored in schools. How many books were challenged between September and November of last year?
evidence: Tracking by the American Library Association’s Office for Intellectual Freedom shows the figure has rocketed up from 156 in the whole of 2020. Find out more on The Overview, a new podcast from The Week

question_sentence: How many so-called ‘ghost flights’ have departed from the UK since the beginning of the pandemic?
evidence: Defined as flights with no passengers or less than 10% of  capacity, the carbon-intensive flights are controversial. But airlines risk losing landing slots if they if they don’t use them

question_sentence: What will school leavers have to do in order to access student loans for university under new government proposals?
evidence: Under the new plans, students who fail to gain a Grade 4 or above – equivalent to a C under the old grading system – or at least two Es at A-level will be barred from student loans

question_sentence: BBC Panorama broadcast an investigation into ‘the UK’s biggest maternity scandal’ at which hospital trust?
evidence: The findings of an inquiry into more than 1,800 incidents over a 20 year period are set to be published in the coming weeks

question_sentence: New research has found that vegetarians are how much less likely to develop cancer than meat eaters?
evidence: Oxford University researchers analysed data from more than 470,000 Brits, discovering that male vegetarians had a 31% lower risk of prostate cancer

question_sentence: A leak revealed which bank to have an extensive list of clients involved in torture, drug trafficking and human rights abuses?
evidence: The leaks point to ‘widespread failures of due diligence by Credit Suisse, despite repeated pledges over decades to weed out dubious clients and illicit funds’, said The Guardian

question_sentence: Russian President Vladimir Putin launched a large-scale military invasion of what country, prompting Western leaders to condemn Moscow?
evidence: Russian forces began an invasion of Ukraine this week, with reports of troops attacking the country from three sides and explosions in multiple cities, including the capital Kyiv.

question_sentence: People around the world were raving about the date 2/22/22 this past Tuesday. The special day is known as a palindrome date. Why?
choices: It reads the same forward and backward
It’s considered the luckiest day of the year
evidence: A palindrome reads the same forward and backward. The last time there was a ubiquitous six-digit palindrome date was November 11, 2011, according to a palindrome enthusiast.

question_sentence: What did AT&T shut down this week?
evidence: AT&T pulled the plug on its 3G network, impacting everything from older phones to home alarm systems and roadside assistance systems.

question_sentence: US health officials are very carefully monitoring if or when Americans might need a fourth Covid-19 vaccine dose. Which country has already rolled out recommendations for a fourth coronavirus shot?
evidence: Israel, Sweden and the UK are among the countries that have already announced recommendations for a fourth booster dose to combat the spread of Covid-19. Although another dose will boost antibodies, researchers say it is not likely to prevent Omicron breakthrough infections.

question_sentence: Which mega-pop star secured a book deal this week valued at more than $15 million?
evidence: Britney Spears inked a $15 million contract with publisher Simon & Schuster. The forthcoming book comes at a time of new beginnings for the Grammy winner. She is engaged to her longtime partner, Sam Ashari, and her 13-year conservatorship ended last year.

question_sentence: The US Defense Department approved the use of 700 National Guard members around Washington, DC, to contain a possible convoy of truckers. What are the truckers planning to protest?
evidence: Organizers of groups of semi-truck drivers say they are planning a major road blockage in DC to protest vaccine mandates, similar to recent protests in Canada.

question_sentence: Uganda has proposed steep penalties for anti-vaxxers, including fines or imprisonment. How many months in jail are lawmakers proposing for unvaccinated people?
evidence: The proposed bill states that those who do not get vaccinated against Covid-19 will be fined 4 million Ugandan shillings (around $1,137) or receive a jail term of six months.

question_sentence: Which beloved animated TV series came to an end this week after 25 seasons?
evidence: “Arthur” has come to an end after 25 seasons on PBS. The popular show that stars an 8-year-old aardvark and his family and friends is the Iongest-running kids animated series in history.

question_sentence: Which of former President Donald Trump’s children is now in talks to voluntarily appear for an interview in front of the House committee investigating the January 6 attack?
evidence: Ivanka Trump, who served as senior White House adviser, is in discussions with the House select committee investigating the January 6 insurrection to voluntarily appear for an interview, her spokesperson and two sources familiar with the probe confirmed to CNN.

question_sentence: Oil prices surged after Russia launched an invasion of Ukraine. What milestone did the price per barrel surpass?
evidence: Global oil prices soared above $100 per barrel – and could go much higher – following Russia’s attack on Ukraine. Brent crude, the global benchmark, last traded above $100 per barrel in 2014.
